conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from the light source.
The shape and size of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source is far away, the shadows are smaller and more defined.
As the light source moves closer, the shadows become larger and less defined.
When the light source moves downward, it gets closer to the objects, making the angle at which the light hits the objects steeper.
With the light source closer, the shadows will extend further from the base of the objects, making them larger and more elongated.
The ice cream cone's shadow will become larger and more elongated, extending further to the left.
The typewriter's shadow will become larger and more elongated, extending further to the left.
The melon's shadow will become larger and more elongated, extending further to the left.
The black and white object's shadow will become larger and more elongated, extending further to the left.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move further to the left.
All shadows will become larger and more elongated.
If the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will all become larger and more elongated, extending further to the left.
